question: Do you use a fossil fuel vehicle?
notes: Driving an electric vehicle charged with green power reduces your carbon footprint.

question: Do you eat meat?
notes: The animal agriculture industry induces suffering on a large scale while using excessive energy.  Eating a vegan diet will improve the health of yourself and the planet.

question: Do you take cruises?
notes: Cruise ships are a major emitter of CO2.

question: Do you fly on airplanes?
notes: Even short flights produce large amounts of CO2.

question: Do you avoid single use plastics?
notes: Most of our plastic ends up in landfills, our oceans, and waterways.  They do not biodegrade either.

question: Do you protect wildlife and/or their ecosystems?
notes: Forests play a vital role in combating climate change and help to protect and strengthen diverse ecosystems.

question: Do you power your home with green energy?
notes: Buildings require substantial resources to establish and maintain.  Green development and more effecient use of energy can have a huge impact.

question: Do you actively reduce your waste?
notes: The less waste we acquire and the more we reuse the less waste we will have to manage.  Mindful consumption will aid clean-up efforts.

question: Do you purchase items from eco-friendly companies?
notes: Purchasing items from verified eco-friendly companies may result in less energy consumption, less waste, and support for ecosystems and communities.

question: Do you bank eco-friendly?
notes: Banks typically support the fossil fuel industry, but new eco-friendly banks support the future of the planet and communities instead.

question: Do you invest eco-friendly?
notes: Investing your money into companies that support our future rather than fight it is a good way to take climate action.  Divest from any and all companies that are bad for our future.

question: Do you purchase carbon credits?
notes: Carbon credits are a good way to fight for the planet when you want to offset your CO2 contributions monetarily to make up for what you cannot reduce directly.

question: Do you purchase items locally when possible?
notes: Supporting local businesses helps build community resiliance and independence.  In many cases, it will also reduce the carbon footprint imposed by transporting products long distances.

question: Do you grow some of your own food?
notes: Growing your own food is not only a good way to reduce your carbon footprint, but it's also good for your health and helps feed your family when local resources are unavailable.
